description: A legendary mountaineer's pub right at the foot of the Llanberis Pass. It's the perfect spot to rehydrate after tackling Snowdon or Crib Goch. The walls are adorned with climbing memorabilia, and the atmosphere is always buzzing with hikers swapping stories. Hearty food and a great selection of ales.

A true hub for the outdoor community in Llanberis. Known for its laid-back vibe, it's where climbers, paddlers, and runners congregate. The food is solid pub grub, perfect for refueling, and they have a spacious beer garden for sunny days. Often hosts live music and events.

Consistently voted one of the best beach bars in the world. Accessible only by foot along the beach or across the golf course, this pub is an adventure in itself to reach. Sitting on the sea wall with a pint watching the waves is an unforgettable Welsh experience.

One of the oldest inns in North Wales, dating back to 1522. It oozes history with low beams and roaring fires. Located within the medieval town walls, it's a great base for exploring the castle and nearby mountains. The food is excellent, focusing on local Welsh produce.

Ideally situated in the heart of Betws-y-Coed, this historic hotel and pub is a favorite amongst mountain bikers riding the Marin Trail. It offers a warm welcome, plenty of space for muddy gear, and hearty meals to satisfy a post-ride appetite.

A grand former coaching inn that dominates the village center. It's a bustling spot with a choice of bars, including a hikers' bar where boots are definitely welcome. Great food, local ales, and a perfect central location for exploring the National Park.

Located in the picturesque village of Beddgelert, this pub is a gem. It offers fantastic food and a cozy atmosphere after a walk through the stunning Aberglaslyn Pass. The beer garden is a lovely spot to relax by the river in the summer.

This brewpub has its own microbrewery on-site, serving award-winning real ales. It's situated right next to the Welsh Highland Railway station and has a campsite, making it a fantastic base for a weekend of steam trains and hiking Moel Eilio.

An 18th-century coaching inn on the banks of the River Conwy. It's a great stop for those exploring the Gwydyr Forest or heading towards the coast. Good traditional pub food and a friendly local atmosphere.

With stunning views towards Moel Siabod, the Bryn Tyrch is a cut above your average pub. It specializes in high-quality local food and has a great selection of craft beers. A perfect treat after a hard day scrambling on Tryfan.
Ideally located for the peaks of the Glyderau and Carneddau. Known for its 'stagecoach' bar and welcoming atmosphere. It's a classic climber's pub, full of character and offering solid, hearty meals.

Situated at the foot of Cadair Idris, this is more of a bar and grill but welcomes walkers with open arms. The building is beautifully renovated, and the food is excellent. A slightly more upscale option for a post-hike meal.

A traditional Welsh pub in the heart of Dolgellau. It's famous for its warm welcome and excellent pint of Guinness. A great spot to mix with locals and listen to some stories after riding at Coed y Brenin.

A classic maritime pub with a wealth of history. Good food, good beer, and a convenient location for the Ffestiniog Railway and the coast. It has a real traditional feel with slate floors and open fires.

Located in the tiny fishing harbour of Porthgain, The Sloop is an institution. Historic, full of character, and serving fresh local seafood (often landed right outside). It's a must-visit when walking the Pembrokeshire Coast Path.

Known as the 'pub on the point', this remote spot is reached by a tidal causeway (accessible at most tides). Famous for its seaweed dishes and fresh seafood. A truly unique location perfect for coastal explorers.
An award-winning pub close to the stunning Barafundle Bay. The food here is exceptional, focusing on high-quality local ingredients. It's the perfect end to a walk around the Lily Ponds.

Perched on the cliff edge with breathtaking views over the Atlantic. The cellar bar is legendary – rustic, bohemian, and incredibly welcoming. A cult favourite among those who know Pembrokeshire well.
A lively and popular pub in Newport. Great for food, local ales, and often hosts live music. It's a bustling hub for hikers coming off the Preseli Hills or the Coast Path.
A traditional pub in the heart of Britain's smallest city. Good pub grub and a great sun terrace for the summer months. Close to the Cathedral and the surfing beach at Whitesands.
Another St Davids staple, offering views of the Cathedral. It's a popular spot with both locals and tourists, serving generous portions of food and a good selection of drinks.
Ideally situated right on the harbour wall in Solva. It's the perfect place to watch the tide come in with a pint and some fresh crab sandwiches. Very dog friendly and welcoming to muddy boots.
A smarter dining pub in Upper Solva. Known for its burgers and seafood. A great option if you want something a little more substantial after a long day on the coast path.

A timeless classic. This pub has barely changed in decades. Set right on the tidal quay, it's perfect for a pint at high tide. Simple, no-nonsense, and incredibly atmospheric. Note: check food availability, often just rolls/pies.
A fantastic seafood pub right on the water in Dale. Much of the seafood is caught by the pub's own boat. A must-visit for foodies and sailors alike.
Steeped in history – this is where the treaty was signed after the Last Invasion of Britain in 1797. A traditional pub with plenty of stories to tell.
A famous coaching inn dating back to 1432. It has heaps of character with oak beams and open fires. The food is excellent, and it's a perfect base for walking in the Black Mountains.

The highest pub in the Brecon Beacons (literally). It's a bunkhouse and pub combined, catering specifically to hikers and bikers. Simple, honest food and a great location for tackling the highest peaks in the Black Mountains.

Reputedly the oldest and most haunted pub in Wales. It has a grim history (it was used as a courtroom and hanging place), but today it offers a warm welcome and good food to those walking the Skirrid.
Located just down the road from the main Pen y Fan car park. It's the nearest pub for a post-summit pint. Traditional, friendly, and used to muddy walkers.
A solid country pub with views towards the peaks. Good food and a friendly atmosphere. A reliable stop-off after a day exploring the central Beacons.
A lovely village pub set high in the Beacons. It has a great reputation for food (especially their pies). A warm and cozy retreat.
Refurbished country inn offering high-quality food and accommodation. Located in the popular hub of Talybont, it's great for cyclists and walkers using the canal or Taff Trail.
A proper real ale pub. Known for its CAMRA awards and extensive beer garden by the canal. It serves simple, good value food and is a favourite with the outdoor crowd.
A gastro-pub offering top-tier food. A great place for a celebratory meal after a big hike. Muddy boots might be better in the bar area, but the welcome is warm.
A highly acclaimed dining pub with rooms. It's relaxed and unpretentious ("eat, drink, sleep") but the food is restaurant quality. Very dog friendly.
Stylish pub with a large terrace overlooking the sea. Famous for its seafood and proximity to the coastal path. A great finish to a walk around the Rhoscolyn headland.
Classic pub location right on the edge of the bay. In summer, you can sit out on the wall; in winter, cozy up by the fire. Historic and very popular.
Nautical-themed pub in the historic town of Beaumaris. Traditional, friendly, and a stone's throw from the castle and pier.
Historic coaching inn with a stylish bar and brasserie. The bar ('The Bull's Head') is full of character with ancient beams and artifacts. Great food and atmosphere.
Modern bar and restaurant located in the dunes. Owned by the Timpson family and run as a training academy for young people. Great views and easy access to the beach.
Upmarket pub/restaurant with a large deck. Great for a post-surf drink or a nice meal. Very popular in summer.
A Gower classic. Traditional pub with a huge fire, serving excellent food. Located under Cefn Bryn, it's perfectly placed for walkers.
Historic pub with a beer garden that has one of the best views in Gower (over the Loughor Estuary). Famous for its seafood and rustic charm. Note: steep access for cars!
Right on the beach at Port Eynon. Recently renovated, it offers a great nautical atmosphere and is the perfect pitstop after a beach day or coastal walk.
The view from the terrace is unbeatable – looking straight down Rhossili Bay. The bar is basic but honest, and it's all about that location.
The surfer's pub of choice in Gower. Located just up the road from the beach, it's always busy with a mix of locals and visitors. Good food, great atmosphere.
Historic drovers' inn turned top-quality gastro pub/hotel. The food is excellent (chef is ex-Marco Pierre White). Ideally located for exploring the wilder parts of Mid Wales.
Right next to the famous waterfalls and the steam railway station. A grand building with a cozy bar and brasserie. Perfect for tourists and hikers alike.
A proper surfer's pub near Hell's Mouth. Stone floors, big fireplace, and a great beer garden. It's the go-to spot after a session in the waves.
One of the oldest pubs in South Wales (1380!). Thatched roof, low beams, and incredibly atmospheric. Located close to the coast path and the unique Aberthaw scenery.
A real gem on the Heritage Coast. Famous for its huge selection of real ciders and perries. It's a proper traditional pub with no frills but bags of character.
Spectacular location overhanging the River Dee rapids. It's a Brunning & Price pub, so expect reliable quality food and a good beer selection. The deck is amazing.
Tucked away in the beautiful Ceiriog Valley. A historic inn with a warm welcome. Ideally placed for those exploring the quieter Berwyn Mountains.
